metadata.case_name: State of Bombay v. Respondents (Civil Appeals Nos. 145, 146, 147 of 1952)

facts.text: Three petitions made in Bombay High Court for writs of mandamus under Article 226 of the Constitution against requisition orders; writs granted and State of Bombay appeals.

Governor of Bombay, acting through Assistant Controller of Accommodation, issued orders under section 6(4)(a) of Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948 in Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952, and under section 5(1) in Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1952, requisitioning premises of respondents.
In Civil Appeal No. 145 of 1952, respondents are uncle (first respondent, tenant) and nephew (second respondent) with family living in requisitioned premises.

In Civil Appeal No. 146 of 1952, premises owned by trust; first and second respondents are trustees; third respondent claims to be licensee living on premises (State contends tenant, but assurance given that possession will not be disturbed).
In Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1952, sole respondent is private limited company occupying premises as tenant for business purposes.
Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948 would have expired in April 1950 but extended by Bombay Act II of 1950; sections 5 and 6 amended by Bombay Act XXXIX of 1950 post-Constitution.
Requisition orders state premises became vacant on or after May 1950; subsequent orders in August 1951 declare requisition for public purpose of housing persons without accommodation.
Petitions filed on 30th April 1951 and 4th April 1951; affidavits in reply on 18th and 19th June 1951.
Housing situation in Bombay acute due to influx of refugees; led to public decency, morals, health issues, lawlessness; rapacious landlords; even government servants lacked accommodation.

Government passed Bombay Land Requisition Ordinance 1947 inviting applications for vacancies; landlords/tenants required to notice vacancies but many suppressed; introduced allotments to first informants of suppressed vacancies if needy.
In 1949 and 1950, Government restricted allotments to Government and public purposes due to excess applications.

In Civil Appeal No. 146, question whether premises within section 4(3) i.e., let or intended to be let; trial judge placed burden on State, State declined evidence seeking ruling on burden; assurance no disturbance of possession.

legal_issues.text: Whether sections 5 and 6 of Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948 (as amended post-Constitution) are ultra vires Articles 19(1)(f) and 31(2) of the Constitution.
Whether requisition orders are ultra vires for lack of public purpose.
Whether Article 19(1)(f) applies to tenants/licensees facing requisition (total deprivation).
Whether public purpose needs to be stated in requisition order itself.
In Civil Appeal No. 146, whether premises fall within section 4(3) (let or intended to be let) and burden of proof.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sections 5 and 6 valid; requisition for public purpose (housing homeless, esp. govt servants; equitable distribution via first informants); purpose proved by affidavits and subsequent orders; no need to state purpose in initial order.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Land Requisition Act 1948 ss.5(1), 6(4)(a); preamble; State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh

petitioner_arguments.text: Burden on petitioners to prove order illegal; they have special knowledge.
Assurance that possession not disturbed in CA 146.

respondent_arguments.text: Sections 5,6 ultra vires Art 19(1)(f),31(2): restrictions not reasonable/in public interest; no public purpose required.
No public purpose: allotments to first informants (spies) not equitable distribution but reward; policy shifted to govt servants only.
Subsequent specification of purpose invalid as afterthought.
Premises in CA 146 not within s.4(3).

court_reasoning.text: Article 19(1)(f) does not apply to tenants/licensees as requisition causes substantial total deprivation of property; turn to Art 31.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Arts 19(1)(f) and 31 cover different fields; 19 assumes existence of property to restrict, not total deprivation.

court_reasoning.text: Act valid under Art 31: provides compensation s.8; public purpose implicit in preamble and ss.5,6 (for State or public purpose).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need for express public purpose if gathered from Act's tenor.

court_reasoning.text: Orders valid: public purpose (housing homeless) proved by affidavits/subsequent orders amid housing crisis; no need to state in initial order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Allotment to needy first informant fulfills purpose; wide discretion to govt; no fraud/discrimination alleged.

court_reasoning.text: Burden on petitioners to disprove prima facie valid order; they have special knowledge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Trial judge erred in placing burden on State.

holdings.text: Article 19(1)(f) inapplicable to substantial deprivation by requisition; Art 31 governs, satisfied with compensation and public purpose.
Public purpose not required in express terms if from Act's intendment; proved here for housing homeless.
Burden on challenger of requisition order.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Articles 19(1)(f) and 31 deal with different subjects.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between Arts 19 and 31; substantial deprivation excludes Art 19.

precedents_cited.case_name: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Art 19 freedoms assume existence of liberty/property.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga
precedents_cited.relevance: Public purpose inferable from Act's tenor/intendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Biswabhusan Naik v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Purpose need not be in order if proved otherwise.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorizes requisition for State/public purpose with compensation; definition of premises.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Property rights; validity of restrictions/deprivation; writs.

outcome.summary: Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 147 allowed, High Court writs dismissed (requisitions valid); Civil Appeal No. 146 dismissed due to Attorney-General's assurance (no disturbance of possession, High Court order stands); no order as to costs throughout.

key_quotes.text: "By substantial deprivation is meant the sort of deprivation that substantially robs a man of those attributes of enjoyment which normally accompany rights to, or an interest in, property."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines when Art 19(1)(f) excluded, applies to requisition.

key_quotes.text: "It is unnecessary to state in express terms in the statute itself the precise purpose for which property is being taken, provided from the whole tenor and intendment of the Act it could be gathered..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds Act's validity via implicit public purpose.

key_quotes.text: "A wide discretion must be left to Government to carry out the policy of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits judicial interference in allotment choices.
